body_html:
Let me guess do you have an Alienware ? I have a similar one which has 980 Nvidia graphic card and 7th generation of i-7 processor. Awesome machine, indeed?
There two ways you can use tensor flow effectively according my experience.

  1. You can dual boot the Ubuntu 17.04 on your SSD drive, not virtual box way. The Linux environment is naive to tensorflow and has compatibility with the latest Python 3 and Nvidia GPU & drivers. for effective and fast usage. Additionally, you can use Alienware graphic Amplifier as well if my guess is right?

  2. Windows support is highly experimental. If you want to stick to it than the following word by word instructions with install tensor flow on windows link will help.

  • Note that the instructions over there recommend using specified versions of Python, cuDNN, and CUDA. Not the latest one. After you achieve it then may try to advance it with the latest versions I guess.

You can dual boot the Ubuntu 17.04 on your SSD drive, not virtual box way. The Linux environment is naive to tensorflow and has compatibility  with the latest Python 3  and Nvidia GPU & drivers. for effective and fast usage. Additionally, you can use Alienware graphic Amplifier as well if my guess is right?


Windows support is highly experimental.  If you want to stick to it than the following word by word instructions with install tensor flow on windows link will help.



Note that the instructions over there recommend using specified versions of Python, cuDNN, and CUDA. Not the latest one. After you achieve it then may try to advance it with the latest versions I guess.
body:
Let me guess do you have an Alienware ? I have a similar one which has 980 Nvidia graphic card and 7th generation of i-7 processor. Awesome machine, indeed? 
           There two ways you can use tensor flow effectively according my experience.

1.    You can dual boot the `Ubuntu 17.04` on your SSD drive, not virtual box way. The Linux environment is naive to tensorflow and has `compatibility ` with the latest `Python 3 ` and `Nvidia GPU & drivers.` for effective and fast usage. Additionally, you can use Alienware graphic Amplifier as well if my guess is right?

2.    `Windows` support is highly experimental.  If you want to stick to it than the following word by word instructions with [install tensor flow on windows](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/42011070/on-windows-running-import-tensorflow-generates-no-module-named-pywrap-tenso) link will help.

 

- Note that the instructions over there recommend using specified versions of `Python, cuDNN, and CUDA`. Not the latest one. After you achieve it then may try to advance it with the latest versions I guess.
